Situation1: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Situation2: They develop a floor plan for a new office, ensuring workspaces accommodate employees’ needs efficiently.
Story: I sit at my desk, blueprints spread before me, the lines and measurements blurring together. My phone vibrates again—another message from Alex. He’s alone at his apartment, the grief of his father’s passing weighing on him, and he needs me. I want to be there, to hold him, to listen, to be the steady presence he’s always counted on. But the deadline for the office floor plan looms. My boss expects a design that anticipates every need, every movement, every comfort for the employees who will fill this space. I stare at the half-finished layout, knowing I can’t afford mistakes. My heart aches for Alex, but my mind races with calculations and spatial arrangements. The guilt gnaws at me—how can I be the partner he needs and the architect my team relies on, all at once? I close my eyes, torn between the urge to rush to his side and the pressure to deliver perfection at work, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in.
